claim: Men can prevent premature baldness by shaving their head to avoid it.

supporting.text: Shaving the head does not affect the biological processes that cause baldness, such as androgenetic alopecia, which is driven by genetics and hormones.

attacks.text: Shaving the head does not affect the biological processes that cause baldness, such as androgenetic alopecia, which is driven by genetics and hormones.
Shaving the head can reduce the appearance of baldness by removing thinning hair, which may psychologically alleviate concerns about premature baldness.
Psychological alleviation does not address the root cause of baldness, which remains unaffected by shaving.
Some studies suggest that scalp stimulation from shaving might improve blood circulation, potentially slowing hair loss.
There is insufficient scientific evidence to conclusively prove that scalp stimulation from shaving significantly impacts hair loss or growth.

supporting.text: Hair loss occurs at the follicle level beneath the scalp, so removing the visible hair by shaving has no impact on the underlying condition.

attacks.text: Hair loss occurs at the follicle level beneath the scalp, so removing the visible hair by shaving has no impact on the underlying condition.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of thicker hair when it regrows, which may psychologically reduce stress-related hair loss.
Stress-related hair loss is a minor contributor compared to genetic factors like male pattern baldness, which are unaffected by shaving.
Shaving can exfoliate the scalp and improve blood circulation, potentially benefiting follicle health.
No clinical studies prove that scalp exfoliation from shaving significantly alters follicle function or prevents balding.

supporting.text: Medical research indicates that treatments like minoxidil or finasteride target the root causes of baldness, whereas shaving is purely cosmetic.

attacks.text: Medical research indicates that treatments like minoxidil or finasteride target the root causes of baldness, whereas shaving is purely cosmetic.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of preventing baldness by removing visible signs of hair loss, even if it doesn't address the underlying cause.
The illusion of preventing baldness through shaving is temporary and does not provide any long-term solution, unlike medical treatments.
Some individuals may prefer shaving for psychological comfort, even if it doesn't prevent baldness, as it gives them a sense of control.
Psychological comfort from shaving does not negate the fact that medical treatments are more effective in addressing the root causes of baldness.

supporting.text: Shaving may create the illusion of thicker hair when it regrows, but it does not prevent the progressive thinning associated with male pattern baldness.

attacks.text: Shaving may create the illusion of thicker hair when it regrows, but it does not prevent the progressive thinning associated with male pattern baldness.
Shaving can stimulate blood circulation in the scalp, which might slow down hair loss by promoting follicle health.
There is no scientific evidence that increased blood circulation from shaving significantly impacts the hormonal causes of male pattern baldness.
Shaving removes damaged hair, making new growth appear healthier and fuller, which can psychologically reduce the perception of baldness.
Psychological perception does not alter the biological progression of male pattern baldness, which is driven by genetics and hormones.

supporting.text: Baldness prevention requires addressing factors like DHT sensitivity, which is unrelated to the act of shaving the scalp.

attacks.text: Baldness prevention requires addressing factors like DHT sensitivity, which is unrelated to the act of shaving the scalp.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of preventing baldness by removing thinning hair before it becomes noticeable.
The illusion does not address the root cause of baldness, which is genetic and hormonal.
Shaving may reduce scalp irritation and improve hair follicle health in some cases.
There is no scientific evidence that shaving improves hair follicle health or prevents baldness.
